text:
¬†@Ben Nevis¬† Of course there was no referendum neither Scotland or England were true democracies back then. The countries were ruled by the desires of like only 3% of the population but common people were generally content (ignorance is bliss) it wasn't until common people were educated for the good of the ruling class that they started to get ideas and be discontent with how representation worked. Lets face it even today about 30% or more (depending on region) of the population that are registered voters don't care enough about politics to actually bother to cast their vote. Northern Ireland is the worst turn out region in the entire UK something like 40% don't vote. If you don't vote you can't be angry when MPs do something you don't like. 

If Scotland wants to truly become independent I will support them I just want them to remember a few things. One they currently publicly spend ¬£2000 per person more than they take-in in taxes those figures are from the Scottish government not Westminster. Two that England/UK gave the EU decades of warnings that reforms were needed and that we weren't happy before we left the EU. The UK did try to reform the EU from the inside even many remainers recognised that there are legitimate problems with how the EU works that's why there are anti EU movements in most EU countries. I just hope that Scotland, Wales and Northern Ireland can give brexit a fair chance with a reasonable time period to see how we fair independent of the EU.

text:
I used to think like that as well but then I realized the monstrous impact that nazi and other radical and prejudice-heavy speeches can have in our society. Even today we see neo nazis still roaming the streets openly and with great pride and I ask you exactly this: Should we allow freedom to speeches that are inherently wrong and harmful for other people's freedom?

I don't think that allowing these people to hate other races and incite war against them will help society in any way shape or form as we do not possess the power to counter-argument every single person in existence and it is inevitable that hate speeches will draw in many listeners as long as we allow them to happen for the good of "Free Speech" for all.

I see this topic just like freedom in general: If you use your freedom to limit other people's (like a murderer, robber or rapist), then you are the antithesis of freedom itself. Just like criminals cannot be allowed to act in their ways we also cannot allow any speech that motivates violence or repression to do as they please.

text:
¬†@Joe¬† you spouted a few very hot takes there.
Some of wich so over the top nonsensical that I don't want to continue this conversation on this level. Therefore I'll leave you, imploring you to read the debate on freedom of speech in the Stanford encyclopedia of philosophy from fall 2016. Have a good read.
author: Xikeyba

text:
‚Äã¬†@Xikeyba¬† You're not understanding, Freedom of Speech doesn't effect someones Personal Freedom or Human Rights, it's an issue about being able to speak freely which the UN and the ECHR say are Human Rights.

In many countries it's a criminal offense to even swear in public or speak bad about an idea. The boundaries of Freedom of Speech start at distributing Child Porn, threatening another human being with the means to do so, and causing mental harm to others. 

You also mention human dignity, if someone has people going after someone so far as to harm their dignity, there's likely a valid reason for that, taking someones dignity and pride as a person is a very hard thing to do meaning that they likely did something bad. And the foundation of Nazism was censorship, not Freedom of Speech which censorship promotes, Germany was differing in that case as obviously at the time the political and ecenomic situation was horrible which also caused a rise in Communism, another far and much worse ideology
author: Joe

text:
I find your opinion to be pretty abhorrent and wrong in so many fundemental ways, but you are allowed to express it, and it has no real impact on my life. Given we had too much censorship rather than none, and suppose the governing power aligned more with my ideology than yours, perhaps I'd have your comment removed. Or, perhaps I'd have you arrested for commenting such stupid ideas publicly. 

The authoritarian Nazi example you have given is totally the opposite of reality, your comment is an example of this. Bad ideas are dangerous when they come from demagogues and the like, but I'm not worried that anyone will take on board what you've said, because it's not a good idea. If any ideas other than yours were censored though however, perhaps we'd end up a more authoritarian society. Reflect on your beliefs, because they do not hold up to scrutiny, and they are harmful to others and crucially yourself. 

Also, you may want to revisit some of the 20th century's worst regiemes and see if they're on the side of censorship or free speech, then you will see which is more dangerous.

text:
The phrases Anti Vaxxer or Conspiracy Theorists are aimed at almost anyone who questions the narrative of governments or mainstream news headlines. 
Think tanks devise phrases and buzz words to stimulate divide and rule or to ridicule and silence anyone who questions the desired direction of social conditioning. Its very clever, because if governments are able to get the public to police themselves, it makes many more controllable and diverts blame that should be aimed at control systems, onto each other. I would not say its hate speech, but it can turn into veiled censorship and hatred of those who question stuff, with good reason. 
I think this presentation by Rowan Atkinson on free speech, is very good and outlines the psychology of manipulation of a self policing society. Particularly this statement he makes on how things are becoming:... 'You may call the new intolerance, a new but intense desire to gag uncomfortable voices of dissent'. 'I am not intolerant', say many people, say softly-spoken highly educated liberal-minded people: 'I am only intolerant of intolerance' and people tend to nod sagely and say', and yet if you think about it this supposedly inarguable statement for a longer than 5 seconds, you realise that all it is advocating is the replacement of one kind of intolerance with another. Which to me doesn't represent any kind of progress at all. Underlying prejudices, injustice or resentments are not addressed by arresting people. They are addressed by the issues being aired, argued and dealt with preferably outside the legal process. For me the best way to increase societies resistance to insulting or offensive speech is to allow a lot more of it. As with childhood diseases, you can better resist those germs to which you have been exposed. We need to build up our immunity to taking offence, so that we can deal with the issues that perfectly justifies criticism raised. Our priority should be to deal with it the message, not the messenger.' 
Rowan Atkinson is a very clever individuate and humor is a good way to communicate. Maybe all the chaos and restrictions happening right now, is like As Above, So Below. Maybe the evolution of humanity happens after all the shit to float to the top and to sort it out.

text:
¬†@Kin Ky¬† Yes, really. The US has homeless. The US homeless are perhaps richer than 500 million in India. India doesn't have free speech. That's the difference. 

Freedom does make a difference. It creates prosperity. Not perfect prosperity but a lot greater than what one gets with lack of freedom. Again, compare India to the US. Free speech appears to be trivial in the context of homelessness but free speech is what allows a society to have lower levels of poverty than it would otherwise have. You have no idea of how terrible poverty is in countries where they don't have free speech. I have seen poverty that you would not believe. Living as a homeless person in the US looks like luxury compared to what the poor in poor countries (see that double 'poor' there) suffer.

text:
Persecution still has social and legal consequences. If you're a racist prick, people will call you out on it. If you follow someone and shout obscenities at them, that's harrassment. If you don't get equal treatment at institutions, that's discrimination which is illegal. Also incitment to violence is illegal, as it is a direct call to violence against a person. If you remove free speech, and people suddenly become racist, homophobic, etc. etc. then there is something wrong with society itself.

Let's put it this way- the government is like a really cool tank. You build it guns to shut down the homophobes and racists, armor to stop people from arguing against its rulings, and it eventually become unstoppable! Everything is fine, right? Well. . . it is, until a far-righter gets into it.

text:
Im not going to say I agree with you 100% but there was an element of that about his defense. Frankly I don't want to see a return to the days of "gay-bashing" or Misogyny disguised as humor. The 60s style of racism disguised with a rye wink and nod. Ive recently seen some re-runs of the likes of Benny Hill, The Two Ronnies etc and they don''t wear well at all. And to some degree, this speech seemed to defend such humor or words as everything else is to PC nowadays. This is evidenced by many of the replies I've read here. 
Now I don't think for one moment Rowan ( as this wasn't MrBean as that's a character) Atkinson wishes to see a return to the days of black face comedy or the Woman at home do a mans bidding humor, and certainly, I can't bring to mind any of his shows ever using it. But sadly when one expresses thought one risks your words being used or twisted by others to support their own expression.

text:
Very well explained Mr Atkinson.

Speaking as a Police Officer that joined shortly after PACE was brought in.
Section 5 POA 1986
"(1) A person is guilty of an offence if he/she:
(a) uses threatening [or abusive] words or behaviour, or disorderly behaviour, or
(b) displays any writing, sign or other visible representation which is threatening [or abusive],
within the hearing or sight of a person likely to be caused harassment, alarm or distress thereby."

was a great tool in our box. It was used against people that were swearing profusely. A warning had to be given before a repeated breach could lead to an arrest. In practice, people were given repeated warnings before having their liberty removed or being reported for the offence.
For my colleagues and I, it was very useful. I could never have imagined that it might be used against a perceived insult as in the case of Harry Miller and others.

text:
Nope.  The right to be offensive should be protected but NOT - absolutely not - the right to insult .  Insults are deliberate and by definition offensive whereas the right to voice an opinion that someone else finds ofensive is not insulting by definition and therefore should be allowed.  I've seen downright nasty bastards behaving in an obnoxious way by going up to total strangers and spewing horrendous verbal abuse at them in a manner which is intimidating because of the nature of the insults and which would be certain to cause a breach of the peace (by inciting a fight) with some people (the type who can take action to stop such insulting behaviour).  Who in their right mind wants such behaviour to be legal?  This seems to be a type of behaviour that the likes of Rowan Atkinson here have overlooked.  Perhaps they don't know that such things happen.  Regardless, it shouldn't be allowed and no civilised nation would allow such a thing.

Now as it happens such behaviour isn't legal BUT only if someone is offended by it (unless a police officer happens to take the view that a breach of the peace is occurring or is likely to occur).  However, this debate that is currently taking place is clouding this fact and is likely to be misinterpreted by idiots everywhere as meaning that it's perfectly fine to insult anyone.  Another example is the obviously racist person hurling racist insults e.g. at a football match.  Is that acceptable?  Of course it isn't.

No, the danger here is the idiots who don't understand the difference between controversial opinions and deliberate insults - and these idiots exist on both sides.

text:
¬†@6EQUJ5 Harden¬† No.  My post EXPLICITLY stated that it is wrong to be insulting e.g. going up to someone to start a fight by calling them something.  

Expressing an opinion in a debate such as the example you have given, is clearly NOT INHERENTLY insulting.  Indeed, to even suggest such a thing in opposition to my statement is beyond ridiculous and suggests that you are a part of this communication problem i.e. you struggle to recognise the difference between that which is INHERENTLY insulting - and intended to be so - and that which is merely an opinion in a debate.

Note that the in a debate part is important i.e. it would be easy for a dispicable person (and there are plenty of them about) to deliberately attempt to cause the same trouble caused by being openly insulting by 'simply and innocently expressing an opinion' e.g. loudly expressing the opinion that people of colour should 'go back to Africa' within earshot of a group of African Americans.  That would be inexcusable and (to those of us who are capable of seeing it for what it is i.e. a phoney pretence at expressing an opinion with the ulterior intention of causing insult ) would be dealt with as a breach of the law.

Given your final sentence, I shall now ignore you because you are either trolling me (which is a the pastime of an imbecile) or so dimwitted as to be beyond education (and you would be advised to get stay out of discussions) i.e. I did not argue that offense taken is a good standard for criminality. text:
Overly simplistic. Some speech is obviously not free. Libel laws and public safety laws are clear evidence of that. The question is therefor not whether all speech is free, but what to allow and what not to allow. 
However, 9 years on from this speech we are all too aware of the danger of letting conspiracy theories and fake news go unchallenged. Banning this speech entirely is not only impossible but self-defeating, as it becomes harder to counter the narrative, allowing it to fester. But letting it run free increases the problem of bigotry and racism, and can create deep political problems like Trumpism or brexit. It can even undermine basic scientific research and sensible healthcare policy. 
A "more robust" debate doesn't help unless we can agree on the terms of the debate. In general, when unfounded and even clearly non-factual arguments are allowed to be used, the debate actually makes things worse. Where arguments touch on subjective and emotional matters (like gender identification or perceptions of sovereignty), different terms may need to apply, but those have to be set out very clearly and enforced. 
And that does actually mean that the state has to set the rules and enforce them to make public debate productive, just like the state has to set the rules and enforce them to make free markets productive.

author: keep itsteel

text:
¬†@keep itsteel¬† Your original comment implies that there is a contradiction between backing free speech and objecting to misinformation. Maybe that's a misunderstanding on my part. But, my point is it's not a contradiction, because free speech, for better or worse, allows people to lie, and even those that oppose free speech don't argue that the 'truth' should be a pre-requisite of speech or opinion. (In fact, usually the opposite. Try speaking the truth about Tiananmen Square in China). So free speech means you can say whatever lies you want without censorship, but it doesn't mean you can't be called out for it. Or sued. I support free speech, but that doesn't mean I have to believe everything that's said, or accept being defamed.

You say free speech will be the death of democracy, but how can you have true democracy without free speech and a free press? As much as I hate all this misinformation and blatant lying on behalf of politicians and the media, silencing their voices will not fix the underlying problems. The fact that many Trump supporters simply refuse to believe demonstrable facts shows (if nothing else) their strength of feeling - you can't just squash that with censorship. You have to tackle it in another way... as Mr. Atkinson says, by contributing to the conversation, not suppressing it.

text: The idea of allowing freedom of speech is objectively a good thing, but how can it be a good thing to tolerate the opinion of a potentially opressive status-quo. Did the Suffragettes tolerate a system that blatantly oppressed them by not giving them the vote? No of course and yet they are mostly celebrated now and not seen as "intolerant". There is a place for both tolerance and intolerance in society, by not tolerating censorship you are engaging in an intolerant act. This is normal. Democracy is simply the best way of determining what society tolerates at anyone given time. Moreover, in many cases you must stand up to things because if you tolerate this then your children will be next.

author: SumRose79

text:
‚Äã¬†@Jt Ho¬† Oh, you and me both, believe me. I completely agree. I've been fortunate enough to have been born in the US where free speech was seemingly a revered notion by everyone, no matter your stance on anything else.

I think too many people here in the US have become spoiled in a sense where they see free speech as nothing more than a legal matter (since it's been one all our lives), and they forget it's much more than that. It's a principled one. They think if there is no such law, then there is no such right, as if speech should be suppressed by default unless otherwise granted by law. I reject this notion entirely. Whether backed by law or not, the idea that everyone is entitled to have their say‚Äîwhether you agree with it or not‚Äîshould be a universally embraced concept if we are to have a healthy society. Like Rowan Atkinson, I hold its importance right up there next to breathing air and drinking water.

What's ironic, is that a lot of those who are in favor of suppressing speech will also claim to be in favor of democracy. When in reality, their idea of democracy is akin to the notion that only those that would vote a certain way should be given the right to vote.
author: Leon

text: ¬†@Leon¬† It is genuinely alarming, though. All these people now saying social media has the right to kick whoever off their services, where were they years ago when others had their livelihoods threatened in court for the exact same thing? It's one thing for tech companies to be so-called "refusing service", but when AWS pulls support for Parler, that's not "Christian bakers refusing to sell cakes to gays" anymore, that's "Christian bakers forming a cabal to pressure the ingredients wholesaler to stop provisioning the baker that will sell to gays". The cases just aren't equivalent, and even if they somehow were, something like Facebook with more users than some countries is on a whole different level than a nobody small business that might see a few hundred a year. My country has never had a right to free speech law and I look on the erosion of these rights in the West with alarm.
author: Jt Ho

text:
They're moving the goalpost, a millimeter at a time.
And for 15 years, you will say "well yeah but they only moved it a millimeter", until one day, you're up against a wall, pinned between it and the goalpost, wondering how you got here.
Laws are amoral.
As such, laws written with morality in mind, can and will be twisted to the polar opposite of it's intention. Not today, not tomorrow, not in a year. But you will live to see it. And all you'll think by then is "How did we let it get to here? And why didn't we stop it?".

Free Speech is a human right for a reason.
Because without free speech, we have no choice but to conform to another's vision.
It's happened before.
Don't let it happen again.

text: 'Free speech' doesn't mean 'free from consequences'. Most people that say they support 'Free speech' (Including probably 99% of commenters here) don't support 'Free speech'. You are hypocrites who support YOUR freedom of speech and people echoing what you believe. You can say whatever you feel like saying and people and organisations will respond how they will respond. Private organisations (Including sites like Twitter, Youtube etc)  have zero obligation so support your free speech. Someone complaining about being censored on youtube/twitter/facebook: Either go stand outside and yell and say the things you want or start your own website. They have almost ZERO legal obligation to support your free speech. If you support the right for a business to refuse to make cakes for gay marriages or clergy who don't want to officiate in gay marriage and THEN complain about being censored on the website of a private business, you are hypocrites.

text:
¬†@bejbejbej1¬† In that scenario, the woman being cat called can solve that situation a couple of different ways: taking a different route, have a friend accompany them, wear headphones/earphones, etc. 

Besides, ignoring these things kinds of things are meant to hold us off until society can better educate themselves on being respectful, like you mentioned earlier. 
But until then what's the immediate alternative? I guess you can ask a nearby police officer for help, since the situation you provided is called harassment. But if there isn't anyone  nearby then in my opinion they should ignore these people and move on with their lives. 
For some people who can't handle these things, cat calling for example, there are resources for that, like therapy, or better yet family and friends who can be their support structure and improve their mental health. 

As for the people that that don't have either of those, they can  improvise based on their situation. And if they can't do that, ask a stranger for help and hope they'll help. And if that doesn't work then they'll just have to deal with it until society becomes better.

author: bejbejbej1

text: ¬†@bejbejbej1¬† While I agree with a lot of what you said, there is a part of what I said that seems to have been misunderstood. I never said to suppress our emotions, only to ignore negative speech. Kind of like feeling anger when called an insult, but choosing to not act on that anger and instead walk away.
author: B_X_B

text: ¬†@B_X_B¬† this is why I mentioned criticism with respect which is progress. Disrespect stems from ignorance, which we can resolve as humans through education and informing. I agree that aggressiveness is not a solution, but this is something that is part of our nature. Our emotions is something we need to control through nurturing and education. Why suppress negative emotions when we can learn to control it, rather than diminish it. Of course creating a respectful society does not happen over night, but neither does removing political correctness. Which is besides the point. Good things are hard to implement in our societies, especially when we can easily find that our societies' are built upon corruption and ignorance. Of course it will be hard to change. I believe telling what people should and should not feel is just as bad as not having any free speech at all. Why is suppressing our emotions more valued than suppressing our speech? Does not make sense to me. If we are able to educate each other and inform each other from early ages - on the importance of respect, similar to how Japan implement this in their education systems. We essentially build a society with a foundation of respect. This way, we can address issues of disrespect calmly, whether it's cultural, religion or racism through education. That's how life is; we can give respect, but not guaranteed it back, same concept applies to kindness, effort, love, money. It does not mean we should not incorporate it within our lives. As cringy as it may sound, the world needs more love, respect, peace and unity. I believe this is the way forward.
author: bejbejbej1

text:
¬†@bejbejbej1¬† " there will always be something that a human being will highly value and if that is threatened in any way, they will feel emotions."

And that's the point I'm trying to make, which is why we need to reduce the impact that negative speech has on us, thus reducing its value, which in turns only leaves us with positives. Don't get me wrong, respectful speech is a good thing to strive for, but it needs to to come gradually and start somewhere first. 

If I could snap my fingers and have everyone be respectful to each other, then I would, but then again that would depend on what I consider respectful and disrespectful. 

Not to mention there are some cultures that consider some words or phrases bad, while others aren't bothered by those same words. 

Ignorance will always exist, but reacting aggressively to it gets us nowhere and we can't impose our will on them to become respectful because that isn't right either. Plus respect goes both ways: we can give respect, but we're not guaranteed it in return, so that leaves us with the response to being disrespected, and how we react to that will determine whether the cycle of disrespect continues.

Building a society based on respectful speech doesn't happen overnight, it needs to begin with ourselves. It's like you said "balance is key", but what I'm saying is that in order to get to that balance we have to achieve it ourselves. 

That's why I suggest that people learn to ignore negative things or at least take a step back to assess the situations they're in. After all, and as childish as this next part sounds: "Sticks and stones may break my bones, but words will never hurt me." And this saying sounds silly, but it does hold a lot of truth, which is why negative free speech needs to be shrugged off when it comes our way.
author: B_X_B

text: ¬†@bejbejbej1¬† all of that requires you placing your trust in a framework devised by biased people. Who decides which speech has value and which doesn‚Äôt? Do you elect a counsel to decide that for you? No one should have that power because before you know it you get censorship of anything unfavorable to those in power. Free speech or bust!
author: Legend 64

text:
‚Äã¬†@B_X_B¬† "suppressing that negative free speech, on the other hand only causes those kind of people to vent their frustrations through other means, and given the two choices, I'd rather they be mean with their words."

"we cannot control what other people say and act, but we can control how we respond and react given the circumstances."



Here's the mind blowing question. What is the purpose of hate speech, negative speech? Humans are capable of criticising something without blatantly being disrespectful. Why build a society where everyone can disrespect everyone and what is the value in that? All in the name of "free speech"? Constructive cristism is different from hate speech. One has a purpose, the other does not. One is good for society, the other is not. To say one should be expected to "go about their day" after racist comments are thrown at you will lead to chaos and division. You might as well supress human emotions as human emotions will always be there, and no matter how much understanding one has and how much one "suppresses" their emotions - there will always be something that a human being will highly value and if that is threatened in any way, they will feel emotions. You might as well start killing people if morality, respect and emotions are thrown out of society in the name of free speech. All for what exactly?

What value can Total Free Speech provide society that Respectful Free Speech can't? Disrespect stems from ignorance. Ignorance can be fixed with education.

The answer is to simply build a society that allows free speech based on respect. Let the difference sink in and you will understand how valuable and different this is. This provides society more value than the current "political correctness" we see in western societies.
Balance is key. People are quick to point and label free speech based on respect or similar idealogies as "dictatorship" which is also ignorance.
I personally do not see the value in "Total" free speech, compared to value and potential of "Respectful" free speech.
author: bejbejbej1

text:
Well you see, that's where building up a resistance to these offenses come in. If people learn to not get offended by these kind of insults, then the words themselves have no power. This means that people can shrug them off and go on about their day. Just think about the internet trolls that try to annoy people and get reactions from them, but if people ignore those same trolls, they go on a little bit longer before getting bored and finding someone else to bother. 

Now let me try to answer you questions as best as I can.

For the free speech question: Yes we should be allowed to say whatever we want and whenever we want, even if its offensive or unpopular. That way people can make the choice to either A: Confront said person with remarks with their own remarks, or if a statement, then argue/debate said statement. B: Just ignore the person in question and walk away, after all we can't force them to change their opinions, and besides they just make it easier for people to avoid them and spent their time better elsewhere.

For the "N" word in the black community question: They could just ignore the guy/lady calling them that word. There's always gonna be people like that so no sense in getting angry and  wasting time on them. 

Finally for your questions on where to draw the line: I believe that there should be no line drawn, because negative free speech only holds as much value as we give it, but if we choose not to get angry about it and discuss what is being said then we can have a better understanding of each other and perhaps understand why the negative speech was said, unless its an insult, then ignoring it is fine. Anyway, suppressing that negative free speech, on the other hand only causes those kind of people to vent their frustrations through other means, and given the two choices, I'd rather they be mean with their words.

In conclusion, we cannot control what other people say and act, but we can control how we respond and react given the circumstances. Anyway hope that my answer was sufficient, unless you weren't expecting a serious answer, still these are good questions that should be asked and I'm glad we have people like you asking them. Have a nice day.

I would agree to that, with the addition/clarification that it's not about the information content of the text spoken, but the intent of the speaker.

text: ¬†@Torgny Andersson¬† All speech is free speech. Even if someone is inciting violence, (which isn't the common definition of hate speech and is a completely separate thing) that should receive a small fine at most if any damage is actually caused.
author: Average Alien

text:
¬†@Average Alien¬† It seems to me that "hate speech" is more about the intent of the words rather than the strict information content of the words. I can say "I hate all people that listen to math metal" with the intent to convey "I have nothing in common fans of math metal", but I can also say it with the intent of encouraging other people to go out and harm people at the local math metal festival.

So where it's obvious it should be legal to state one's opinion on music, it less obvious that encouraging violence should be legal. Saying "there is no hate speech" completely misses the point.

I think the question you have to answer is: would you want a person that convinces other people commit crimes through their words alone be outside the reach of the law?

text:
‚Äã¬†@Tsusday¬† I find your speech to be incorrect and full of non-factual and opinionated errors. I think you should be arrested for this or at least fined. 

What a garbage, dangerous, and evil stance to have. You think that people shouldn't have the ability to believe in whatever they want, and share those beliefs? If people want to believe in the flat earth and talk about it, it is their RIGHT to do so. If people want to be open about their racism, that is their RIGHT to do so. 

Your ww2 germany argument is so idiotic I don't even know where to begin. There are so many layers of stupidity it's difficult to unravel. For starters, no one could "ban" the nazis because national socialism was a LEGITIMATE political party, just like the communist party. The problem isn't the ideology itself, it's the fact that one ideology had the ability to obtain complete control of the country. The nazis specifically banned speech they deemed to be incorrect, or politically offensive, just like you would love to do. Ban all "incorrect" speech. Your ideology is no better than the nazis. 

People's personal beliefs and expression of those beliefs DID NOT cause ww2. You know what did? Authoritarianism. The same ideology you subscribe to. 

I don't think you understand what free speech actually is. It is the ability to express whatever you want without the government being able to dictate what you can and cannot say. Scientific discoveries were made precisely because someone once went against what was known to be true and presented an idea which might've been considered false and ridiculous. Like heliocentrism. The church considered that to be false and thus banned it. 

Banning "factually incorrect" speech would very rapidly devolve into banning all speech the government deems to be incorrect and thus tyranny would inevitably ensue. 

When an idiotic idea gets expressed, like for example, the flat earth conspiracy, or racism, the best course of action is to present counter arguments and show the world why those ideas are incorrect and not based of facts. This demonstrates that you are open for debate and questioning, and it's an educational exercise for everyone. 

Now lets compare this form of open discourse with your tyrannical ideology. In your fantasy world, what would happen is this: Someone expresses their belief in the flat earth, or whatever other nonsense. They then get arrested and silenced immediately.  People witness this happening. They begin to question why their beliefs would warrant such a reaction. What if they're correct? After all it's not like you can even see their arguments anymore. More and more people begin to get arrested or fined and silenced after making factual errors of any sort. Eventually a genius inventor somewhere comes up with a revolutionary discovery that has the ability to change the world, but is silenced because his ideas aren't in line with current knowledge. Eventually you yourself accidentally slip up, forget to check your sources, and make a factual error. Bam, arrested, and silenced. Fast forward a few hundred years, and you've now got a system running on outdated incorrect facts, and a massive revolution on your hands, filled with people that have been radicalised and believe that the silenced flat earthers and racists were right all along, because there's no discourse or way of hearing their arguments, so hey, they might just be right. Why should they trust their government if they can't even hear the other side after all? Cut out a mans tongue and all you prove is that you are scared of what he has to say because you know it is true, as the saying goes. And just like that you've got a garbage, dystopian, collapsing society where all new controversial ideas with a possibility of being incorrect and shut down and a slippery slope effect where outlawing speech knows no bounds. 

Science THRIVES on contradicting ideas, new ideas, and opposition. Without opposition and questioning, science is no different from religion. Science needs to be questioning in order to progress and to stay accurate. For every 1000 people that the flat earth conspiracy deceives, it helps 100,000 more educate themselves on astronomy and mathematics. For every 1000 people that anti vaxxers deceive, it helps 100,000 more learn how vaccines truly work and why they should trust them. For every 1000 people that become racist, 100,000 more can use the flaws in the opposition's arguments to become anti racists. 

I'm hoping you're just naive and you don't really hold such an evil ideology though. But even if you do, that is your right of free speech.

1) Slander with intent to ruin someone's livelihood and career (affects individuals life in a physical way)

That's it. Everything else falls under free speech. There is no such thing as hate speech. Everything besides those two points should be free speech. Suppressing speech doesn't lead to less racism. It leads to less racist speech. Two very different things. Racist speech is free speech. The most despicable vile speech you can imagine....is free speech. Everything that doesn't physically affect someone's well being or livelihood is free speech, the end.

We use some minor forms of censoring over full free speech in Canada. And to me, it leads to less racism, less dumbasses going around spewing lies and nonsense. Less fanaticism and hatred by itself. Judging by a difference between countries that use some sort of minor censorship vs free speech (US vs UK, Canada, Australia and others)  I can say that using the hate speech concept is practical and efficient.

text:
I find it very difficult to stomach Rowan Atkinson‚Äôs public mockery of Christianity, and indeed of Christ, but I cannot deny him his right to do so. 

But freedom of speech should never mean that you can say what you wish with impunity. Like arrows, words have to fall somewhere. Freedom of speech should also come with respect for others, and a far greater virtue is to judge it prudent on occasion to curb what one says despite one‚Äôs right to say it, for the sake of the common good.

text:
The problem I have with the current state of free speech is with the weaponization of "hate speech" labels in some of the more heated left vs right matters. Without giving any specific examples, if liberals do not agree with conservatives, they do not argue, they instead label their opponent's views as being hate speech and basically begin bullying campaigns against those who support the conservative or libertarian viewpoint. On some more common issues it almost becomes akin to brainwashing, we're told over and over that something is hate speech we eventually start to just believe it and police ourselves.

I'm trying not to be biased against liberals, but I just can't think of any liberal talking points that are actively touted as being hate speech, there might be some people making noise here and there, but nobody listens. Hate speech suppression is purely the realm of liberals, simple as that, they are effective at gatekeeping free speech by changing definitions and successfully convincing the public that these differences matter when it comes to free expression. They have created a culture of fear amongst ourselves, and it creates a very hostile environment for open discussion.

text:
Such a shame that the World is in the state its in now....Just because the book '1984' is a good story....it doesn't mean that the concept of Right-Think & Wrong-Think should spill over into every facet of human society.....Is this our role-model now????

Here's to hoping that objectivity, tolerance and compassion will begin to take  center stage again....because our society is taking a very dark path indeed.

If you cannot even address a problem....how can you positively solve it?

Humans need to evolve...and evolution is a painful & messy business...but I think that we all have a duty to leave this world a better place then when we entered it....but that can only be done with intelligence, reasoned discussion and honesty...only then. can we move forward.

But that's just my opinion....which is the whole point.

I maybe wrong...and if that is the case....I welcome the debate....as long as both parties in a conversation are at least willing to listen to each other's point of view....then that (at least) is a start.

Factionalism and Tribal thinking does not work....when people become so easily swayed by the court of popular opinion....something has to change.

text:
It's not just about "taking offense". Who cares about "offence". Offense is an issue of etiquette.  What a lot of people don't realize is that some kinds of speech isn't just "offense" but socio-cultural verbal abuse. We are highly social animals and as such we do not like being rejected by our tribe. Cultivating a climate of rejection can drive people to depression, anxiety and suicidal ideation. Cultivating that climate of rejection through racism, sexism, homophobia and transphobia has coffins-in-the-ground impact through words alone.

Yelling Fire in a theatre is one example of a reasonable limit on free speech. Inciting a riot to overthrow the government over false allegations of voter fraud is another. Verbally abusing or harassing someone to the point that they commit suicide is a third. 

We should never put something so high on a pedestal that we aren't willing to make exceptions.

text:
Sadly we are dealing with an increasing group of people in positions of power and importance who view any sort of comment, critique, joke or mockery of something they view as sacred as utterly intolerable and will, ironically, resort exactly to the sort of heavy-handed methods they claim to be fighting against. The radical, politically correct left claim to fight for tolerance, social justice and diversity, but are currently creating systems where people are punished for holding an opinion which hasn't been greenlit by mob rule, people are punished or rewarded based on the color of their skin and seem to be of the opinion that "diversity" simply means "no white people". 
I'm of the honest opinion that we will soon miss Trump. He could trigger these self-appointed zealots simply by existing, goading them into exposing themselves and their radical views with a mere Tweet. The fact that a simple Tweet could rile people up so much that vandalism, riots and murders are being comitted by supposedly intelligent and educated people shows how utterly intolerant and anti-liberal the arbiters of free speech, tolerance and human rights truly are.

text:
In response to the concept of "Intolerance of Intolerance", Atkinson's argument is flawed. Any action, as tool, is moral based on the context of that action.  We can agree that censorship is immoral but censorship of racism isn't immoral because racism itself has no moral value.

Rioting in general is immoral but rioting to fight against injustice may be moral. The beginning of the LGBT equality movement was the Stonewall Riots where the community rioted against police harassment.  Riots may be immoral unless they are rioting against a great immoral action. 

We can preserve free speech as a moral act while censoring racism. As this is specifically about the domain of the legal system, it's not the court of public opinion, I can trust judges to accurately weigh the moral value of the thing being censored.

you have your political spectrums confused. 

any form of hard left or hard right governance is about silencing. But this is not what this speech is about. 

This is about the right of an individual to express themselves, and at the same time be responsible for those words or acts. They go hand in hand. Exercising the right to freedom of expression is not a carte blanch get out free card if in doing so you seek to degrade, abuse, or put down others who don't have the right or ability to defend themselves.

In a decent society, we treat others with respect and in doing so get respect. When you don't then respect is denied to both parties.

text:
Given the context of this video it is ironic that the same people that want to restrict the scope of the word fascism are most often those arguing elsewhere that language evolves. Twisting terms so words can be used as weapons is a core tool in the suppression of freedom of speech. It is the method employed by these new age 'moderators' to intimidate people into silence.

As in all things it is the intent of the meaning that matters. I understood the reference above about Political Correctness. I think whether you take fascism here to be an analogy for authoritarian suppressive behavior, or an evolution of the word used literally, the difference is irrelevant.

The truth is, when you set yourself apart to be a position of authority on what people can and can't say, without being elected by a majority, you are in the wrong. That is the basis of dictatorship. So many heinous regimes believed absolutely in what the were doing. So the idea that ones beliefs can justify such action is empty and self deluded. Whether we call this behavior 'fascism' or create a new word is by the by. It has the exact same core ethos of forcing ones view of how humanity should operate on everyone else. Seeking to exert control because you feel divinely and self righteously that you are a superior human being. Willing to go to harsh and extreme lengths to protect your self appointed authority and quell opposition.

The worrying thing is the belief that this is somehow virtuous. It is always done for the 'greater good', but that is a perspective, and is rarely proven to be the case. Mussolini was probably a true hero in his own eyes. It is definitely something worth considering when self congratulating yourself for your 'heroic' efforts in silencing those pesky voices you don't agree with. I bet he felt the exact same sense of self pride.

text:
All of you nearly have it but not quite there. It's quite funny.

F = a regime that goes for one direct philosophy.
Authoritarianism which can be in F too, makes this the whole oppressing, etc lalalala. But F itself is just the regime that is going towards something with a disregard of any other opinion. This is why it is sometimes, but wrongly, equated to imperialism.

M = an ideology. You can't deny this. He wrote numerous columns on his philosophy and beliefs. He then wrote extensively against those things he wrote in the late 1800s but every M seem to forget this fact.
However, correct M is not C and is kind of S but isn't at the same time. I call it "bad socialism".

C = a regime which has full state control over land, its peoples and their expressions. It's based on commune not individual basically. Some C's believe this to be a good trait of a regime but in practice this always ends up as "your tribe vs my tribe" which is just bad for humanity generally.
This also has authoritarianism aspect to it, which generally leads to secret police, mass state media, and such.

What Euphoria was saying is what you call "Anarchy" but a utopic version of that anarchism which typically is from your dreamers. Becuase in reality a stateless society run by people would again just become "your tribe vs my tribe" and general chaos. You need certain controls and law in a society, we are not neolithic my fellow human anymore; we have too many people to govern :)

Just want to also point out there are no wings, so saying x = this and y = that is like that saying BBC scotland has a show that the English version doesn't get and therefore the BBC England version is wrong or vice versa. It is all based on your philosophy and your experiences in life. Idealism, here, is what makes it hard to justify right. Becuase, in an ideal world, everyone would agree (I would hope) that everyone else needs to live at least in some capacity. Therefore, really any ideology and philosophy you have is based on your own experiences and opinions about what you have thought, taught or seen over your years.

¬†@Bryan mark¬† no ones changing any definitions apart from you. The ideology of the far left is communism. Communism is literally a stateless moneyless society where the means of production are controlled by the people and there is NO GOVERNMENT. 

The fact that you believe free healthcare shouldn‚Äôt be a right shows me how much of an idiot you are. I live in the UK where we have the NHS. I pay 20% tax and NI and my healthcare is covered. No extra charges for anything. I tore my shoulder last year and got an MRI scan literally within a week. If it‚Äôs an emergency it would be quicker. If I want one straight away I would have the option of private healthcare and I could pay for it. The reason people travel to the US for healthcare is because they are better for certain treatments but it‚Äôs a shame that the people living in the country can‚Äôt afford it. It‚Äôs amazing to me that you also don‚Äôt realise that you would literally be paying less if you had socialised healthcare.

The Conservative right does not support better opportunities. To go to Uni you need money which discourages people who are raised in poverty. People born to lower income families are discouraged from going to hospital or calling an ambulance simply because it will cost money. 

The difference between the far left and far right is, the far left wants to work as a community, while the far right is individualistic and only thinks about themselves. Which is dangerous and isn‚Äôt great for longevity. 

(Not sure if this makes a lot of sense, had about 8 beers before I wrote this)

text:
¬†@Bryan mark¬† that is only true if you view politics as fairly one-dimensional and do not separate sociopolitical thought from political economics. 

For me, both left and right have social policies that are almost the exact opposite of their economic politics. 

On the left: further left you go, the more state-centric the economic policies become (from public health care all the way to total centralised economies and state monopolies). Conversely, the left's sociopolitical policies are much more liberal and conducive to individualism with minimal state intervention (gay rights, drug legalisation, access to abortion, etc).

One the right, the exact opposite is true: the right is all about laissez-faire economics, deregulation, all the way through to limiting state-provided health care and other welfare. However, the same cannot be said for its standpoint on social issues, which has traditionally been authoritarian in nature (criminalisation of homosexuality, narrowing the gap separating Church and state, heavy focus on law and order).

text: ¬†@Sparkly Airtime Muffin Poo Bear¬† Well at the moment you live in a country where you have the right to bare arms, you have the right to free speech but you don‚Äôt have the right to healthcare as it is considered a privilege (yes I know it‚Äôs a right and doctors can‚Äôt turn you away). In the US anyone can be treated as long as they have money and if they don‚Äôt, they either miss out or build up mountains of debt lasting a life time. This makes healthcare virtually inaccessible to the vast majority of those living below the poverty line. It costs less to buy a gun, something made for taking lives, than it does to get an MRI, something for saving lives. You have the right to free speech and you can protest. This is accessible to everyone, while once again healthcare still isn‚Äôt accessible. You also pay corporations for your healthcare who then pay the hospitals to provide you treatment. I live in the UK. We have a government that provides free healthcare as a right. I can break my finger playing rugby, go to the hospital and get treated in half an hour, and not pay anything (apart from what I‚Äôve paid through taxes already). I could also tear my shoulder and get an MRI in under 3 hours and leave without paying a thing.

text:
¬†@pancake ghosty¬† I agree what we identify as racism has been "lowered" but not for the reasons you describe but because there systemic cultural biases that results in making the lives of black people (as an exmple) objectively worse.

There's a reason "Death by a thousand papercuts" is an expression. It can apply to racism. If we culturally view black men as being criminals or "thugs", we are more likely to call the police on them. When the police arrive, they are more likely to treat black people with suspicion. It is more likely that it will escalate to violence and as a concquence more lblack people die.

That's racism. I mean what else would you describe it as but this cultural bias against black people that results in violence?

But it's not even violence and death... but black men are less likely to be hired despite being qualified. That's racism.

Black people are given harsher sentences. Black people are more likely to be convicted of offenses that the police have discretion over. There are disproportionately more black people in prison. It's racist to assume that there's something about being  black that warrants them being there.

We may have less lynchings in our society now (not none) but it doesn't mean racism has ended.

So yes, the bar has been lowered as to what we recognise as racism... and for good reason... because racism isn't over.
author: majeric

text:
The bar has been lowered as to what racism actually is. Now racism is calling someone a name or even expressing an idea. According to some groups simply being white makes you a racist regardless of what you say or do. Racism used to be defined as violent acts against others because of colour, country etc. So the bar is being lowered now constantly due to political correctness. That's the issue with modern PC culture and we see it across the board with many different topics, not just racism.
It's a political trick, to put it basically. They give one group in society a moral dilemma, then they perpetuate that dilemma in order to incite a disparity between the people. Then they (the state) swoop in and impose regulation to "help" these groups. The regulation is welcomed by said groups because the people want to be morally upheld and they believe the problems in their society are these "racists" or bad eggs. The state comes out on top as now they have more control than they had previously. Also you will find if you look critically, the issues are never resolved. The state ultimately has done nothing for the people in these situations except bring in more rules, laws and regulation that helps and protects them, not the people.
author: pancake ghosty

text: ¬†@Occam's Stubble¬† Ah. I'd think considering a site like Twitter has servers in almost all places, it would have to apply to local laws no? Causing a baseline TOS to be needed to be set. As for the kiddie stuff, yeah. That's a huge problem on Twitter.
author: Potto

text:
¬†@Potto¬† As a platform, their TOS would be limited to criminal activity and direct incitement to violence. Someone urging his supporters to "fight for justice" would not qualify. 

As an aside, I've heard there's a ton of kiddie porn on Twitter that they have yet to take down despite being told about it.
author: Occam's Stubble

text: ¬†@Occam's Stubble¬† Hm, I didnt know that. Would the ToS still be there to serve as their baseline rules though? Because that's what I was getting at with trump. Not exactly causing the riots, yet almost pointing towards doing it subtly. Which broke ToS. Ofcourse, antifa should be held to the same standard which Twitter doesnt do mainly because people report more of the right than the left. Though I would assume TOS would still have to be followed, even with 230
author: Potto

text:
¬†@Potto¬† I think you missed the point of Section 230. It establishes a difference between a publisher and a platform under the law. A publisher is held liable for the contents on their site while a platform is not. 

The New York Times can decide whether or not to publish your letter to the editor but FaceBook cannot decide whether or not to allow your comment except in a very strict set of circumstances that are spelled out in the law.
author: Occam's Stubble

text: ¬†@Occam's Stubble¬† You raise a fair point. Though, correct me if mistaken, the law classing social media as utility is still under review. I think it's important for free speech to exist, though with things like Twitter or Facebook, at the end of the day right now atleast, they're private platforms, and that's where it catches 230, the company would be required to follow if classed as utility, the platforms however, not. I believe there should be platforms that openly support free speech, 4chan, Gab, etc etc. Though for Twitter, it is their platform. I dont agree with it per se, same as I dont agree with the Baker scenario. Though it is what it is until social media platforms are held under the same light.
author: Potto

text:
¬†@Potto¬† If you read Section 230 of the Communications Decency Act, it talks about how social media is an excellent platform for free speech as it is the new public square. In order to ensure that free speech occurs there, platforms like FB, YT, and Twitter are given protection from legal liability over their content. 

That is why this is different from the baker. The baker did not give up his right to refuse service in exchange for some kind of legal protection. If those platforms no longer want to allow free speech, that is their choice but they need to petition the government to reclassify them as publishers under the law thus removing those protections. As it is, they want to have their cake and eat it, too.
author: Occam's Stubble

text:
Never before has tolerance been as intolerant as it is today. And those who claim to be tolerant the most, are usually the most intolerant. These days, I'm not even sure I want to be considered tolerant anymore. If being tolerant means prosecuting people for voicing their (unpopular) opinion, or cracking a joke someone could potentially find offensive, I think I'll give tolerance a pass. It has lost its value anyway. Tolerance inflation, so to say. The more you seem to hear of it, hear the actual word being spoken, hear people remind you to be more tolerant when, in fact, they themselves are anything but, the less it is worth and nowadays the word is everywhere. And it is worth nothing anymore! 
Besides, one doesn't eliminate intolerance by shutting people up, one just makes people stay silent about it. Just saying. Shutting people up is just a means for some snowflakes to be able to live in their idealistic bubble undisturbed. In the 60ies and 70ies, at least they got stoned in order to do that but didn't force other people to stop saying what they didn't want to hear on a global scale. Good old times!

text: I remember as a child in the 1980's that if people wanted to make "free money" they would sue someone, and so we became a litigious society all with a negative connotation.  Those who waged knee-jerk lawsuits came to be seen as opportunistic and shallow.  Fast forward 40 years later and we're having the same discussion around censorship.  I hope that the same thing happens to censorship.  In the marketplace of ideas, good ideas rise, bad ideas fall but everyone gets a place at the table.  That is how it SHOULD be.

text:
Has anyone watched the GOODIES lately, A kids show from the seventies, Yes a kids show that was the essence of ENGLISH humour. Now this kids show would be highly inappropriate Today.
Why do I ask? Have we become less funny?
Are we smarter now?
Do we care for people more?
I would suggest not, It as more to do with the fear of what may become, a person may get offended, they haven‚Äôt yet but just in case??? So it is the fear of nothing, well at this point in time. The fear of fear itself.
So all this PC is trying to achieve what? I would suggest control, because if you have rules, policies in a country or workplace for something that people haven‚Äôt been offended by, but maybe, it hasn‚Äôt happen yet, so you are acting legally on a assumption?
So here we are, in a world where the top man of America can‚Äôt express free speech on a social media app. This is where we have arrived.
